sa5:1.2: One time, the Buddha was staying at Anāthapiṇḍada’s Park in Jeta’s Grove of Śrāvastī.
sa5:2.1: It was then that the Bhagavān addressed the monks,
sa5:2.2: “When you don’t know, don’t understand, and don’t become free of desire for form, your mind isn’t liberated.
sa5:2.3: When your mind isn’t liberated, you aren’t able to stop suffering.
sa5:2.4: Thus, when you don’t know, don’t understand, and don’t become free of desire for feeling … perception … volition … consciousness, your mind isn’t liberated, and you aren’t able to stop suffering.
sa5:3.1: “Monks, if you know, understand, and become free of desire for form, your mind is liberated, and you’ll be able to stop suffering.
sa5:3.2: Thus, if you know, understand, and become free of desire for feeling … perception … volition … consciousness, your mind is liberated, and you’ll be able to stop suffering.”
sa5:4.1: The monks who heard what the Buddha taught then rejoiced and approved.
